awd_titl_txt: Excellence in Research: Unveiling the Potent Photo-activated Antiviral Functions of Carbon Dots and Derived Hybrid Dots
awd_abstract_narration:
Non-technical Summary: 
Carbon dots (CDots) are nanoparticles of diameter <10 nm. The core in a CDot is made of carbon, and the coating on the surface is composed of nontoxic organic or biological molecules. CDots have recently been demonstrated to have highly effective antibacterial function under visible/natural light, which is associated with their unique optical properties and photoinduced redox characteristics. Building upon the known antibacterial function of CDots, this project expands the research and development of CDots to target viruses. Viruses have different structures, and replicate in a different way from bacteria, so specifically designed and modified CDots and hybrid dots with the core composed of carbon and other materials are synthesized and tested to identify those that are most effective to target viruses. The successful execution of this project could lead to the development of effective antiviral agents with potential applications for preventing viral transmission and infection, addressing some of the critical issues in public health and safety. The project also provides excellent opportunities for the research development of faculty, the training of underrepresented minority students, and the recruitment of students into the pipeline to STEM programs at North Carolina Central University.

Technical Summary: 
This project is to develop carbon dots (CDots) and novel carbon-based hybrid dots to target viruses. The hybrid dots, with TiO2 doping or dye photosensitizer encapsulation in core carbon nanoparticles, are designed to significantly improve the optical properties and enhance photodynamic effects, thus exploiting the synergistic effect of the two constituents within the hybrid dots for more effective antiviral activities. With the use of two structurally different model viruses, murine norovirus (MNV) and vesicular stomatitis virus (VSV), the project has three research aims: 1) Evaluation of the antiviral activities of selected CDots platforms against representative viruses, towards the understanding of property-function correlations by using various viral binding assays and infectivity assays. 2) Exploration of selected hybrid dots  (C/TiO2 and C/dye photosensitizer hybrid dots) for more effective antiviral activities against MNV and VSV, including a systematic evaluation on the correlation between major CDots properties such as dot surface charge, dot size, and optical properties and their antiviral effectiveness. 3) Mechanistic exploration of CDots and hybrid dots' antiviral actions, focusing on the interactions between the dots and viruses, reactive oxygen species (ROS) generation, viral particle integrity, and damages in viral proteins and viral genomic integrity by using various chemical/biochemical analytic tools and high-resolution microscopy methods. The successful execution of this project leads to the development of effective antiviral agents with potential applications for preventing viral transmission and infection.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The most significant outcome of this project is the development and establishment of carbon dots (CDots) and derived hybrid dots as a new class of high-performance visible light-activated antiviral agents. The project team designed and carried out a tremendous number of experiments on the synthesis, property characterization, and function assessment of CDots and carbon-derived hybrid dots, along with mechanistic and theoretical analysis. The results from the project have proven that CDots and derived hybrid dots possess potent photodynamic antiviral activity. They represent a class of promising nanoscale biomaterials for significant biological applications. This project has been a major success, as reflected in 16 peer-reviewed scientific publications and a number of scientific conference presentations and other outreach activities, contributing majorly to the broad CDots research field.

 

CDots are small carbon nanoparticles with surface organic functionalization in a special core/shell structure, which is analogous to that in the well-established semiconductor quantum dots (QDs), but unlike those QDs, CDots are benign and nontoxic. CDots have strong absorptions in the visible spectrum, with absorptivities much higher than those of dye photosensitizers, enabling extremely effective and efficient light activation to drive photodynamic process. The associated antimicrobial activities are much beyond those of classical dye photosensitizers and conventional semiconductor QDs.

 

On the intellectual merit, the project team explored the mechanism of action for CDots’ photodynamic inactivation of viruses, achieving the understanding that the inactivation is due to the highly reactive redox pairs (electrons/holes) and the classical reactive oxygen species (ROS) produced in the photodynamic process damaging viral proteins and genomic RNA/DNA to diminish the infectivity of virus. The analysis of property-function correlations revealed that the major factors for enhanced antiviral activity include CDots’ surface functionalization and associated positive surface charges, and excited state properties reflected by observed fluorescence quantum yields. Further, the project team systemically compared the classical CDots and the nano-carbon/organic hybrids, which are dots samples produced by thermal carbonization of organic precursors, and revealed the divergence in antiviral activities between the two kinds of dot samples despite their similarities in optical spectroscopic and photoexcited state properties. The project findings have contributed majorly to the advance of the CDots research field and the development of technologies derived from CDots and their based hybrid nanomaterials, establishing a solid foundation for future NSF projects on the further investigation of the nanomaterials for biological applications.

 

On the broader impacts of the project, CDots antiviral technology represent a technological area that could be a potential disinfection strategy for the prevention and control of the spread and infections of viruses, including those viruses that are new and more infectious and/or deadly. Especially, learning from the Covid-19 pandemic, this project has been at the forefront of the emerging field, and will eventually be developed into technologies that benefit the public health. On the education, the project has been a successful platform for training and mentoring undergraduate and graduate students and other researchers, especially those from underrepresented groups, at NCCU, a historically black college and university (HBCU). It has provided extensive hands-on experience for students to learn research-related technologies and laboratory skills, literature searching, problem-solving, and analytical skills, and other excellent co-curriculum activities beyond the traditional classroom teaching, which have afforded them with competences for their pursuing future career goals. The project has contributed to the development of our next generation of scientists and human resource development. Further, this project has greatly increased the research productivity of HBCU faculty, strengthened the institutional resources and research infrastructures in biomaterial-related research fields, and allowed the faculty to build up strong collaborations with research-intensive universities.
